choices.text: Posterior to the superior mesenteric vein
Behind the first part of the duodenum
Anterior to the inferior vena cava

questions.text: The uncinate process of the pancreas is situated:
questions.solution:
Pancreas Anatomy:

  • The pancreas is a retroperitoneal organ divided into the head, body, and tail. The head lies within the curve of the duodenum, and the uncinate process passes behind the superior mesenteric vein.
  • Relations: The superior mesenteric vein joins the splenic vein behind the neck of the pancreas to form the portal vein. The pancreatic tail extends to the splenic hilum.

Explanation:

Option A) Posterior to the superior mesenteric vein: Correct. The uncinate process projects from the head of the pancreas and lies behind the superior mesenteric vein and artery.

Option B) Anterior to the aorta: Incorrect. The body of the pancreas lies in front of the aorta, but the uncinate process is related to the superior mesenteric vessels.

Option C) Behind the first part of the duodenum: Incorrect. The duodenum lies anterior to the head of the pancreas, not the uncinate process.

Option D) Anterior to the inferior vena cava: Incorrect. Although the uncinate process lies near the inferior vena cava, it is most closely associated with the superior mesenteric vessels.

Key Points:

  • The uncinate process lies posterior to the superior mesenteric vessels.
  • The neck of the pancreas is important in the formation of the portal vein.

questions.text: Which of the following pancreatic cells produce insulin?
questions.solution:
Pancreatic cells Consist of different cell types distributed throughout the pancreas:

  • Beta cells (75%) produce insulin.
  • Alpha cells (20%) produce glucagon.
  • Delta cells (5%) produce somatostatin.

Key Points:

  • Beta cells, which produce insulin, form the inner core of the islets of Langerhans.

questions.text: Malrotation of the ventral pancreatic bud during embryonic development results in:
questions.solution:
Pancreatic Embryology:

  • The pancreas develops from two buds (ventral and dorsal) during the 5-6th week of gestation. Malrotation of the ventral bud results in annular pancreas, which can cause duodenal obstruction.
  • Developmental Anomalies: Pancreas divisum occurs when the ducts fail to fuse properly.

Explanation:

Option A) Annular pancreas: Correct. Annular pancreas is caused by abnormal rotation of the ventral pancreatic bud, which encircles the duodenum and may cause obstruction.

Option B) Pancreas divisum: Incorrect. Pancreas divisum results from the failure of fusion between the dorsal and ventral pancreatic ducts, leading to a separate drainage of the ducts.

Option C) Agenesis of the pancreas: Incorrect. Pancreatic agenesis refers to the congenital absence of part or the entire pancreas and is not related to the rotation of the ventral pancreatic bud.

Option D) Ectopic pancreas: Incorrect. Ectopic pancreas occurs when pancreatic tissue is found in locations outside the pancreas, not due to abnormal rotation.

Key Points:

  • Annular pancreas can cause duodenal obstruction and present with symptoms such as vomiting and feeding intolerance in neonates.
  • Pancreas divisum is usually asymptomatic but may predispose to pancreatitis.

questions.text: A 45-year-old male presents with severe abdominal pain radiating to the back. Which of the following is the most specific test for pancreatic damage?
questions.solution:
Pancreatic Enzymes

  • Serum Amylase: Elevated within a few hours of pancreatic damage; not diagnostic of acute pancreatitis as levels can rise in other conditions.
  • Serum Lipase: More sensitive and specific than serum amylase for pancreatic damage but less widely available.

Other Causes of Raised Amylase:

  • Upper GI tract perforation,
  • mesenteric infarction,
  • torsion of intra-abdominal viscus,
  • ectopic pregnancy,
  • macroamylasaemia,
  • renal failure,
  • salivary gland inflammation.
  • Imaging: CT scan of the pancreas is more valuable if confirmation of diagnosis is required.

Explanation of Options:

Option A) Serum amylase: Incorrect. Elevated in acute pancreatitis but lacks specificity due to potential elevation in other gastrointestinal and salivary conditions.

Option B) Serum lipase: Correct. Lipase is more specific to the pancreas than amylase. Elevated serum lipase levels are more reliable for diagnosing acute pancreatitis as lipase remains elevated for a longer period and is more pancreas-specific.

Option C) Urinary amylase: Incorrect. Not commonly used but can be elevated in acute pancreatitis.

Option D) Amylase-creatinine clearance ratio: Incorrect. An older test that is now rarely used, as more reliable tests are available.

Key Points:

Serum lipase is more specific than serum amylase in diagnosing acute pancreatitis.

questions.text: A 40-year-old patient with recurrent episodes of pancreatitis undergoes an MRCP, revealing that the majority of the pancreatic secretions drain through the minor papilla. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Pancreas Divisum

  • Failure of the embryological ventral and dorsal parts of the pancreas to fuse, causing drainage mainly through the minor papilla.
  • Incidence: Found in 5-10% of cases during autopsy or imaging (ERCP, MRCP); higher in patients with recurrent pancreatitis (25-50%).
  • Clinical Presentation: Recurrent acute pancreatitis, chronic pancreatitis, or pancreatic pain.
  • Diagnosis: MRCP, EUS, or ERCP (sometimes secretin-stimulated).
  • Treatment: Endoscopic sphincterotomy or surgical intervention (sphincteroplasty, pancreatico jejunostomy) in symptomatic patients.

Explanation:

Option A) Annular pancreas: A rare congenital anomaly where the pancreas forms a ring around the duodenum.

Option B) Pancreas divisum: Correct. It is a congenital condition where the dorsal and ventral pancreatic ducts fail to fuse, causing the majority of secretions to drain through the minor papilla. This can lead to recurrent pancreatitis.

Option C) Cystic fibrosis: A genetic disorder affecting multiple organs, including the pancreas, leading to thick secretions, but it doesn’t specifically cause altered drainage patterns.

Option D) Congenital pancreatic cyst: These are cystic lesions present at birth, typically asymptomatic, and unrelated to the abnormal drainage described in this scenario.

Key Points:

  • Pancreas divisum is a congenital anomaly associated with recurrent pancreatitis. Diagnosis is typically confirmed with MRCP or ERCP.

questions.text: A 5-year-old boy presents with chronic respiratory disease and steatorrhea. His mother mentions that he tastes "salty" when kissed. Sweat chloride levels are elevated. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Cystic Fibrosis

  • Genetics: Autosomal recessive disorder due to mutation in the CFTR gene on chromosome 7, leading to abnormal chloride movement across cell membranes.
  • Systems Affected:
    • Lungs (chronic respiratory disease)
    • intestines (meconium ileus)
    • pancreas (exocrine insufficiency)
    • liver (cirrhosis and portal hypertension).
  • Diagnosis: Sweat test showing sodium and chloride levels above 90 mmol/L confirms diagnosis.
  • Pancreatic Involvement: Pancreatic duct blockage leads to replacement of the exocrine pancreas, causing pancreatic exocrine insufficiency.
  • Treatment: Pulmonary physiotherapy, antibiotics, pancreatic enzyme replacement, and low-fat diet.

Explanation:

Option A) Pancreatic insufficiency: Incorrect. Although pancreatic insufficiency is common in cystic fibrosis, it is not a standalone diagnosis. It is a consequence of CF, not the primary disease.

Option B) Cystic fibrosis: Correct. CF is a genetic disorder characterized by elevated sweat chloride levels, chronic respiratory disease, and pancreatic insufficiency leading to steatorrhea.

Option C) Meconium ileus: Incorrect. Meconium ileus can occur in newborns with cystic fibrosis but is not the diagnosis in this chronic case.

Option D) Portal hypertension: Incorrect. Portal hypertension causes gastrointestinal and vascular issues but does not present with respiratory symptoms or steatorrhea.

Key Points:

Sweat chloride levels above 90 mmol/L are diagnostic of cystic fibrosis. Pancreatic exocrine insufficiency results in fat malabsorption and steatorrhea.

questions.text: A 50-year-old male presents with severe epigastric pain radiating to the back, vomiting, and fever. He has a history of alcohol use. His serum lipase is markedly elevated, and his C-reactive protein (CRP) is >150 mg/L. On admission, his Ranson score is 4. how should this case of acute pancreatitis be categorised?
questions.solution:
Acute Pancreatitis- classification

Aetiology:

  • Gallstones: 50-70% of cases.
  • Alcohol abuse: 25% of cases.
  • Others: Post-ERCP, drugs (e.g., corticosteroids, azathioprine), hypertriglyceridemia, hypercalcemia, viral infections, trauma.

Classification (Revised Atlanta 2013):

  1. Mild Acute Pancreatitis:
    • No organ failure.
    • No local or systemic complications.
  2. Moderately Severe Acute Pancreatitis:
    • Organ failure that resolves within 48 hours (transient organ failure).
    • Local or systemic complications without persistent organ failure.
  3. Severe Acute Pancreatitis:
    • Persistent organ failure (>48 hours).
    • Single or multiple organ failure.

Severity Assessment:

  • Ranson and Glasgow Criteria: Both systems classify pancreatitis as severe when 3 or more factors are present.
  • CRP: Levels >150 mg/L at 48 hours indicate severe pancreatitis.

Key Points:

  • Gallstones and alcoholism are the two most common causes of acute pancreatitis. CRP >150 mg/L at 48 hours indicates severe pancreatitis.

questions.text: A 65-year-old male with a history of diabetes presents with acute pancreatitis. His Ranson score on admission includes the following values: WBC count >16 x 10^9/L, and blood glucose >11 mmol/L. On repeat evaluation at 48 hours, his arterial oxygen saturation is <60 mmHg, and his serum calcium is 1.8 mmol/L. According to the Ranson score, how many criteria does this patient meet for severe acute pancreatitis on admission?
questions.solution:
Explanation of Options:

Option A) Incorrect. The patient meets more than 2 criteria for severe pancreatitis.

Option B) correct. The patient meets 3 criteria.The patient meets 3 criteria: age >55, WBC >16 x 10^9/L, blood glucose >11 mmol/L on admission.

Option C) Incorrect. The patient meets less than 4 criteria.

Option D) Incorrect. The patient meets 3 criteria.

Key Points:

  • Ranson and Glasgow scoring systems are widely used to predict the severity of acute pancreatitis.
  • A score of 3 or more factors at 48 hours indicates severe pancreatitis.

choices.text: Percutaneous drainage of the infected fluid

questions.text: A 55-year-old male is admitted to the hospital with severe acute pancreatitis. His condition worsens after 72 hours despite supportive care, and a contrast-enhanced CT scan reveals necrotic areas in the pancreas. The patient has a fever and elevated white cell count. Fine-needle aspiration of the necrotic fluid reveals purulent material.What is the next best step in management?
questions.solution:
Pancreatic Necrosis

Sterile vs. Infected Necrosis:

  • Sterile Necrosis: Should not be drained unless the patient shows signs of clinical deterioration or infection.
  • Infected Necrosis: Confirmed by fine-needle aspiration and requires intervention.

Initial Management: Conservative treatment is preferred initially, but infected necrosis requires either endoscopic or percutaneous drainage.

  • Surgical Necrosectomy: Considered when less invasive measures (percutaneous or endoscopic drainage) fail, or the patient continues to show signs of sepsis.

Drainage Techniques:

  • Percutaneous Drainage: First-line for infected necrosis.
  • Endoscopic Drainage: Can be done by inserting a stent to drain into the stomach.
  • Surgical Necrosectomy: Last resort if other treatments fail.
  • Necrosis can lead to local and systemic complications, including sepsis, multiorgan failure, and persistent pancreatic fluid collections.

Key Points:

Pancreatic necrosis can be sterile or infected; infection requires intervention. Percutaneous drainage is the first-line treatment for infected necrosis.

questions.text: A 45-year-old male presents with a history of severe acute pancreatitis four weeks ago. He now reports persistent abdominal discomfort and early satiety. A CT scan reveals a well-defined fluid collection adjacent to the pancreas. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Pancreatic Pseudocysts

  • A pancreatic pseudocyst is a collection of pancreatic juice enclosed by a wall of fibrous or granulation tissue, typically arising after an episode of acute pancreatitis or trauma.
  • Clinical Features: Patients may present with persistent abdominal pain, discomfort, early satiety, or even a palpable mass. More than half of pseudocysts communicate with the pancreatic duct.

Diagnosis:

  • Imaging: Ultrasound or CT scan typically shows a well-circumscribed fluid collection adjacent to the pancreas.
  • Differential: Must differentiate from other cystic lesions like cystic neoplasms. EUS with fluid aspiration for CEA levels and cytology helps differentiate.
  • Complications: Pseudocysts can rupture, become infected, or cause obstruction of adjacent structures. Larger pseudocysts (>6 cm) are less likely to resolve spontaneously and may require intervention.

Management:

  • Most pseudocysts resolve spontaneously.
  • Intervention: Required if the pseudocyst persists beyond 12 weeks, causes symptoms, or complications develop.
  • Surgical drainage: Most definitive, with low recurrence rates.

Explanation:

Option A) Acute peripancreatic fluid collection (APFC) typically occurs in the early stages of acute pancreatitis (within the first week), whereas a pseudocyst requires 4 weeks or more to form.

Option B) Pancreatic abscesses are rare and usually present with signs of infection such as fever, rather than just discomfort and early satiety.

Option C) Correct. A pancreatic pseudocyst is a fluid collection that develops after an episode of acute pancreatitis, usually more than 4 weeks later, and is defined by a well-formed wall of granulation or fibrous tissue.

Option D) Solid pseudopapillary neoplasms are rare pancreatic tumors and are unlikely in this clinical scenario.

Key Points:

A pseudocyst requires more than 4 weeks to form after an acute pancreatitis episode.

questions.text: A 45-year-old male with a long-standing history of alcohol use presents with chronic abdominal pain radiating to the back and steatorrhea. Abdominal CT scan reveals calcifications in the pancreas. Which of the following investigations is the further management?
questions.solution:
Chronic Pancreatitis - Investigations

  • Early Markers: Serum amylase is elevated in the early stages, but not reliable in chronic pancreatitis

Imaging:

  • CT scan: Shows calcifications and structural damage.
  • MRI: Outlines gland and damage; calcifications are better seen on CT.
  • MRCP: Non-invasive but less detailed than ERCP.
  • ERCP: Most accurate for evaluating pancreatic ductal anatomy, helps in identifying strictures, dilatation, and stones.
  • Sonographic Findings: Hyperechoic foci, dilated duct, hyperechoic margins, presence of stones, cysts, and lobularity.

Explanation of Options:

Option A) Serum amylase: Serum amylase is elevated only in the early stages of pancreatitis and not reliable for chronic cases.

Option B) MRI scan: Although useful in evaluating the overall morphology of the pancreas, it is not as accurate as ERCP for ductal anatomy.

Option C) ERCP: Correct answer. ERCP is the most accurate investigation to elucidate the anatomy of the pancreatic duct. It can also guide therapeutic interventions like stent placement or removal of stones.

Option D) MRCP: MRCP is non-invasive and useful for evaluating biliary and pancreatic ducts, but it lacks the therapeutic capabilities of ERCP.

Key Points:

  • ERCP is the gold standard for evaluating pancreatic duct anatomy and guiding therapeutic decisions.
  • Pancreatic calcifications are a hallmark of chronic pancreatitis on imaging.

choices.text: Continue analgesics and re-evaluate after 3 months

questions.text: A 50-year-old male with chronic pancreatitis presents with intractable pain, despite being on opioid analgesics. Imaging reveals a markedly dilated pancreatic duct. What is the most appropriate next step in the management of this patient?
questions.solution:
Chronic Pancreatitis - Treatment

  • Medical Management:
  • Treat Addiction: Help stop alcohol and tobacco use, involve a dependency counsellor.
  • Pain Management: Eliminate obstructive factors, escalate analgesia, consider coeliac axis block for intractable pain.
  • Nutritional Therapy: Low-fat, high-protein diet; pancreatic enzyme supplements with meals; correct vitamin malabsorption.
  • Pharmacological Measures: Steroids (only in autoimmune pancreatitis), micronutrient therapy (e.g., methionine, vitamins C, E, selenium).
  • Endoscopic/Radiological/Surgical Management:
    • Pancreatic Duct Obstruction: Endoscopic pancreatic sphincterotomy, stent placement (temporary), ERCP for stone removal.
    • Pseudocysts: Drained internally under EUS or percutaneous guidance.
  • Surgical Interventions:
    • Pancreatic Head Mass: Pancreatoduodenectomy or Beger procedure.
    • Duct Dilation: Longitudinal pancreaticojejunostomy or Frey procedure.
    • Distal Disease: Distal pancreatectomy.
    • Diffuse Disease: Total pancreatectomy may relieve pain but with significant morbidity.

Explanation:

Option A) Coeliac plexus block: Useful in managing pain, but not first-line when there's a clearly treatable anatomical obstruction like ductal dilatation.

Option B) Endoscopic pancreatic duct stenting: Correct answer. Decompression of an obstructed pancreatic duct can relieve pain in patients with ductal hypertension.

Option C) Total pancreatectomy: it is associated with significant morbidity.

Option D) Continue analgesics: Insufficient in the presence of an obstructed duct.

Key Points:

Surgery is reserved for obstruction relief or complication management. Pancreatic enzyme supplementation and nutritional support are vital.

questions.text: A 58-year-old male presents with painless jaundice, pruritus, dark urine, and pale stools. He reports unintentional weight loss and recent onset of diabetes without a family history or obesity. On examination, he is icteric with a palpable gallbladder. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Pancreatic Head Tumours

  • Common Presentation: Painless jaundice, pruritus, dark urine, pale stools, and recent-onset diabetes in individuals over 50 without family history or obesity.
  • Important Signs: Courvoisier sign (painless, palpable gallbladder) suggests a non-stone obstruction, usually neoplastic.
  • Advanced Presentation: Weight loss, epigastric discomfort, and vague abdominal symptoms. Back pain indicates possible retroperitoneal infiltration.
  • Risk Factor: New-onset diabetes, especially in older patients, may be an early indicator of pancreatic cancer.
  • Diagnosis: Based on clinical presentation, supported by imaging such as CT or MRI, and biopsy.

Explanation:

Option A) Incorrect. Chronic pancreatitis typically presents with epigastric pain and a history of alcohol use or gallstones but lacks painless jaundice and recent-onset diabetes.

Option B) Incorrect. While ampullary carcinoma can present with jaundice, it is less commonly associated with a palpable gallbladder or recent-onset diabetes.

Option C) Correct. Painless jaundice, recent-onset diabetes, and a palpable gallbladder (Courvoisier sign) are classic signs of pancreatic head carcinoma.

Option D) Incorrect. Gallstones may cause jaundice but are typically associated with colicky pain and not with a Courvoisier sign.

Key Points:

Painless jaundice is a hallmark of pancreatic head carcinoma.

questions.text: A 45-year-old male presents with severe abdominal pain radiating to the back. His serum amylase is elevated, and a contrast-enhanced CT (CECT) scan is performed, which shows diffuse pancreatic enlargement and two fluid collections. Pancreatic necrosis involving 40% of the pancreas is also noted. What is the patient's CTSI score, and what is the likely morbidity rate?
questions.solution:
Pancreatic Inflammation: Diffuse pancreatic enlargement with two fluid collections gives a score of 4

Pancreatic Necrosis: 40% necrosis gives a score of 4.

CTSI Total: Inflammation (4) + Necrosis (4) = 8

Morbidity: Based on a CTSI score of 8, the morbidity rate is 92%.

Computed Tomography Severity Index (CTSI) for Acute Pancreatitis

  • CTSI Components: Evaluates pancreatic inflammation and necrosis on a contrast-enhanced CT scan.

Key Points:

CTSI: Combines pancreatic inflammation and necrosis to predict outcomes. Morbidity/Mortality: Higher scores indicate significantly increased morbidity and mortality.

questions.text: Which of the following best describes an acute necrotic collection occurring more than 4 weeks after the onset of necrotizing pancreatitis?
questions.solution:
Acute Pancreatitis - Morphological Features

Explanation:

Option A) Pseudocysts occur after interstitial edematous pancreatitis, not necrotizing pancreatitis, and are fluid collections without solid components.

Option B) Correct. Walled-off necrosis is a well-defined, encapsulated collection of liquid and solid components that occurs after 4 weeks in cases of necrotizing pancreatitis.

Option C) Acute peripancreatic fluid collections are seen early in the course of interstitial edematous pancreatitis.

Option D) Interstitial edematous pancreatitis refers to inflammation without necrosis and does not typically result in walled-off necrosis.

Key Points:

Walled-off necrosis forms after 4 weeks in necrotizing pancreatitis. Pseudocysts are associated with interstitial edematous pancreatitis.

questions.text: A 55-year-old male is being evaluated for a cystic lesion in the pancreas found on routine imaging. The lesion has a CEA level of 220 ng/mL. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Cystic Neoplasms of the Pancreas- management

  • CEA ≥192 ng/mL: Indicates mucinous cystic neoplasm (MCN).
  • Serous Cystic Neoplasm: Low CEA levels, benign, rarely requires surgery.

Explanation:

Option A) Serous cystic neoplasm is typically benign with a low CEA level.

Option B) Correct. A CEA level ≥192 ng/mL is indicative of a mucinous cystic neoplasm.

Option C) Solid pseudopapillary neoplasm typically presents with solid and cystic components, not elevated CEA levels.

Option D) Simple cysts usually have a low CEA level and are benign.

Key Points:

CEA levels guide diagnosis of mucinous vs. non-mucinous neoplasms. Surgery is recommended based on risk factors, including high CEA, duct dilation, and nodules.

questions.text: A 58-year-old male presents with jaundice, weight loss, and upper abdominal pain. He is diagnosed with a periampullary carcinoma. What is the most appropriate surgical intervention?
questions.solution:
Pancreaticoduodenectomy (Whipple Procedure)

  • Indications: Tumours involving the head of the pancreas, ampulla, distal bile duct, and duodenum.
  • Surgical Technique:
  • Removal of the head of the pancreas, duodenum, gallbladder, and part of the bile duct.
  • The procedure involves reconstruction with pancreatico jejunostomy, hepaticojejunostomy, and gastrojejunostomy.
  • Complications:
    • pancreatic fistula, delayed gastric emptying), mortality (significantly reduced with improved technique).
  • Distal Pancreatectomy: Performed for tumours in the body/tail of the pancreas and involves splenectomy.

Explanation:

Option A) Distal pancreatectomy is used for tumors in the body or tail of the pancreas, not the head.

Option B) Correct. Pylorus-preserving pancreaticoduodenectomy (Whipple procedure) is the standard surgical treatment for tumors involving the head of the pancreas.

Option C) Longitudinal pancreaticojejunostomy is not a treatment for pancreatic tumors.

Option D) Frey procedure is unrelated to tumors in the pancreas.

Key Points:

Pancreaticoduodenectomy is the procedure of choice for tumors of the pancreatic head.

choices.text: Central calcification with a sunburst appearance

questions.text: Which of the following is a characteristic feature of serous cystic neoplasms (SCNs) of the pancreas on CT imaging?
questions.solution:
Cystic Neoplasms of the Pancreas

Explanation:

Option A) Incorrect. Eggshell calcification is more typical of mucinous cystic neoplasms (MCNs).

Option B) Correct. Central calcification with radiating septa, creating a "sunburst" appearance, is a hallmark feature of SCNs on CT in about 10% to 20% of patients.

Option C) Incorrect. Mural nodules suggest a malignant potential, often seen in mucinous cystic neoplasms (MCNs).

Option D) Incorrect. SCNs do not communicate with the pancreatic duct, unlike intraductal papillary mucinous neoplasms (IPMNs).

Key Points:

SCNs show central calcification and a sunburst appearance on CT.

MCNs are more common in middle-aged women and can show eggshell calcification. Surgical intervention is recommended for symptomatic or large (>4 cm) lesions.

questions.text: A 55-year-old woman with a 10-year history of rheumatoid arthritis presents with recurrent infections and fatigue. Physical examination reveals splenomegaly and multiple nodules over her elbows. Laboratory tests show anemia, neutropenia, and thrombocytopenia. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Felty Syndrome

  • Felty syndrome is a rare complication of long-standing rheumatoid arthritis, characterised by the triad of:
    • Rheumatoid arthritis (RA)
    • Splenomegaly
    • Neutropenia (low neutrophil count)
  • Clinical Presentation:
    • Recurrent infections due to neutropenia.
    • Fatigue, fever, and weight loss.
    • Splenomegaly and possibly hepatomegaly.
    • Skin ulcers and rheumatoid nodules.
  • Diagnosis: Based on the presence of RA with splenomegaly and neutropenia.
  • Treatment: Managing underlying RA (with disease-modifying antirheumatic drugs, DMARDs), and treating infections and neutropenia (sometimes using granulocyte colony-stimulating factor, G-CSF).

Explanation:

Option A) Systemic lupus erythematosus (SLE): SLE can cause similar symptoms, but splenomegaly and neutropenia in a patient with long-standing rheumatoid arthritis (RA) make Felty syndrome more likely.

Option B) Sjögren’s syndrome: Sjögren’s is associated with dry eyes and mouth, but not typically with splenomegaly and neutropenia in RA.

Option C) Felty syndrome: Correct. This condition is a complication of long-standing RA and is characterized by a triad of rheumatoid arthritis, splenomegaly, and neutropenia.

Option D) Polyarteritis nodosa: Polyarteritis nodosa is a vasculitis that may involve multiple organs, but the clinical picture is not consistent with Felty syndrome.

Key Points:

Felty syndrome: Triad of RA, splenomegaly, and neutropenia.

choices.text: The splenic artery arises from the superior mesenteric artery and runs behind the tail of the pancreas.
The gastrosplenic ligament contains the splenic artery and splenic vein.
The splenic artery runs along the upper border of the pancreas and gives rise to the short gastric arteries.
The splenic vein joins the inferior mesenteric vein to form the portal vein.

questions.text: A 35-year-old male presents with left upper quadrant abdominal pain. Imaging shows an enlarged spleen. During surgical planning for a splenectomy, it's important to be aware of the vascular and ligamentous connections of the spleen. Which of the following correctly describes the vascular supply and ligaments of the spleen?
questions.solution:
Anatomy and Vascular Relations of the Spleen

  • Weight and Dimensions: Normal adult spleen weighs 75-250 g and measures approximately 10 × 7 × 3 cm.
  • Location: Lies in the left hypochondrium between the gastric fundus and the left hemidiaphragm, with its long axis along the 10th rib.
  • Ligaments:
    • Gastrosplenic ligament: Connects the spleen to the stomach, containing short gastric and left gastroepiploic arteries.
    • Splenorenal ligament: Connects the spleen to the left kidney and contains the splenic vessels and the tail of the pancreas.
  • Arterial Supply: The splenic artery arises from the celiac trunk and runs along the upper border of the pancreas. It gives off short gastric arteries and the left gastroepiploic artery.
  • Venous Drainage: The splenic vein joins the superior mesenteric vein behind the pancreas to form the portal vein.
  • Lymphatic Drainage: Drains via retropancreatic nodes to the celiac nodes.

Explanation:

Option A) Incorrect. The splenic artery arises from the celiac trunk, not the superior mesenteric artery.

Option B) Incorrect. The gastrosplenic ligament contains the short gastric and left gastroepiploic arteries, not the splenic artery or vein.

Option C) Correct. The splenic artery arises from the celiac trunk and runs along the upper border of the pancreas. It gives rise to the short gastric and left gastroepiploic arteries, which pass between the layers of the gastrosplenic ligament.

Option D) Incorrect. The splenic vein joins the superior mesenteric vein, not the inferior mesenteric vein, to form the portal vein.

Key Points:

The splenic artery arises from the celiac trunk and runs along the pancreas. The splenic vein joins the superior mesenteric vein to form the portal vein.The gastrosplenic ligament contains short gastric arteries.

choices.text: Splenectomy and repair of the aneurysm

questions.text: A 35-year-old woman, who is 30 weeks pregnant, presents with sudden onset abdominal pain and collapse. She is found to have hypotension and signs of intraperitoneal bleeding. Imaging reveals a ruptured splenic artery aneurysm. Which of the following is the most appropriate management?
questions.solution:
Splenic Artery Aneurysm

  • Prevalence: Found in 0.04-1% of postmortem exams.
  • Demographics: Twice as common in women, with a high risk of rupture in pregnant women (especially during the third trimester).
  • Clinical Presentation: Often asymptomatic until rupture, which mimics splenic rupture and carries a high mortality rate, particularly in pregnant women.
  • Imaging: Detected on plain radiographs or CT scans. A bruit may be present in some cases.
  • Management:
    • Unruptured: Embolization or stenting can be considered. Surgery is indicated for younger, asymptomatic patients.
    • Ruptured: Splenectomy and repair of the aneurysm are the treatments of choice, with high mortality if untreated.

Explanation:

Option A) Incorrect. Observation is inappropriate in the case of a ruptured aneurysm with hemodynamic instability.

Option B) Incorrect. While embolization is an option for unruptured aneurysms, ruptured aneurysms require immediate surgical intervention.

Option C) Correct. Splenectomy and repair of the aneurysm are the definitive treatments for a ruptured splenic artery aneurysm.

Option D) Incorrect. Anticoagulation would worsen the bleeding and is contraindicated.

Key Points:

  • High-risk group: Pregnant women, with almost inevitable fetal death in cases of rupture.
  • Treatment depends on symptoms and rupture status, with surgical intervention for rupture.

questions.text: A 35-year-old woman presents with easy bruising, prolonged bleeding after minor injuries, and menorrhagia. On examination, she has purpura and petechiae. Her platelet count is 45 x 10^9/L. She is diagnosed with chronic idiopathic thrombocytopenic purpura (ITP). What is the next best step in management?
questions.solution:
Idiopathic Thrombocytopenic Purpura (ITP)

  • Pathophysiology: Autoimmune destruction of platelets via antiplatelet antibodies (IgG) targeting specific platelet membrane glycoproteins.
  • Clinical Types:
    • Acute: Seen in children, often following infections, usually self-limiting.
    • Chronic: Common in adults, particularly females aged 15-50, and persists for more than 6 months.
    • Clinical Presentation: Purpura, petechiae, mucosal bleeding, and prolonged bleeding after trauma.
    • Complications: Intracranial haemorrhage, though rare, is the leading cause of death.
  • Investigations:
    • Platelet count <60 × 10^9/L.
    • Bone marrow aspiration shows increased megakaryocytes.
  • Management:
    • First-line: Corticosteroids.
    • Refractory cases: Splenectomy or immunosuppressants.
    • Acute bleeding: Platelet transfusion may be necessary in severe cases.

Explanation:

Option A) Incorrect. Platelet transfusions are usually reserved for emergency bleeding situations and are not first-line for ITP.

Option B) Incorrect. Splenectomy is indicated for refractory or relapsing cases, not as the first step.

Option C) Correct. Corticosteroids are the first-line treatment for ITP to suppress the autoimmune response.

Option D) Incorrect. Antiplatelet therapy would worsen thrombocytopenia and is contraindicated.

Key Points:

First-line treatment in adults and children: Short courses of corticosteroids. Splenectomy is effective in refractory or relapsing cases, with laparoscopic splenectomy being the preferred approach.

questions.text: A 45-year-old male undergoes an elective splenectomy for hypersplenism secondary to cirrhosis. Postoperatively, he develops fever, abdominal pain, and leukocytosis. Imaging reveals fluid collection, drain has amylase rich fluid. What is the most likely cause of his complication?
questions.solution:
Complications of Splenectomy

  • Pancreatic Fistula: Damage to the tail of the pancreas during splenectomy can lead to pancreatitis, localised abscess, or pancreatic fistula.
  • Post-Splenectomy Thrombocytosis: This is a frequent complication, and if platelets exceed 1 million/mL, prophylactic aspirin is recommended.
  • OPSI (Opportunistic Post splenectomy Infection): Can be life-threatening, particularly due to encapsulated organisms such as S. pneumoniae, N. meningitidis, and H. influenzae.
  • Immunisation: Preoperative vaccines (pneumococcus, meningococcus, H. influenzae) and annual influenza vaccination are recommended. Vaccination should ideally be given 2 weeks before surgery.
  • Prophylactic Antibiotics: Controversial but indicated in children and immunocompromised adults.

Key Points:

Pancreatic fistula is a notable complication due to damage to the pancreatic tail during splenic vessel ligation.

choices.text: Daily antibiotic prophylaxis until the age of 10
Daily prophylactic aspirin to prevent thrombosis
Immunization for S. pneumoniae, N. meningitidis, and H. influenzae every year

questions.text: A 10-year-old child underwent splenectomy at age 3 for hereditary spherocytosis. The parents are concerned about recurrent infections. Which of the following preventive measures is most appropriate?
questions.solution:
Opportunistic Post splenectomy Infection (OPSI)

  • OPSI: Life-threatening infection due to encapsulated organisms (S. pneumoniae, N. meningitidis, H. influenzae) following splenectomy.
  • The risk of overwhelming sepsis is greatest within the first 2–3 years after splenectomy
  • Antibiotic Prophylaxis: Recommended for children and immunocompromised adults. Daily penicillin is typically prescribed.
  • Vaccination: Preoperative vaccines include pneumococcus (every 5 years), meningococcus (every 5 years), and H. influenzae (every 10 years). Annual influenza vaccination is also recommended.

Explanation

Option B) Correct. Children who have undergone splenectomy before the age of 5 should receive daily prophylactic antibiotics, especially penicillin, to prevent infections with encapsulated organisms, continuing until at least age 10

Option A) Pneumococcal vaccination should be administered every 5 years, not annually.

Option C) Aspirin is given for thrombocytosis, not for preventing infections.

Option D) Immunization is recommended every 5 years for pneumococcus and every 10 years for Hib; yearly vaccination is not required.

Key Points:

Daily antibiotic prophylaxis is recommended for children under 16 to prevent OPSI. Vaccination against encapsulated organisms is crucial in all splenectomised patients.

questions.text: Which of the following is a common indication for splenectomy?
questions.solution:
Splenectomy

Indications for Splenectomy:

  • Trauma: Both accidental and iatrogenic injuries.
  • Oncological: Part of en bloc resection, diagnostic splenectomy in hematologic malignancies.
  • Haematological: Spherocytosis, ITP, and hypersplenism.
  • Portal Hypertension: In association with shunt or variceal surgery.

Explanation:

Option A) Correct. Trauma is the most common indication for splenectomy.

Option B) Correct. ITP is a common hematologic condition treated with splenectomy when refractory to medical management.

Option C) Correct. Diagnostic splenectomy is performed in certain hematologic malignancies when splenomegaly or hypersplenism complicates the clinical course.

Option D) correct

Key Points:

Common indications: Trauma, ITP, spherocytosis, hematologic malignancies.

questions.text: A 55-year-old male is undergoing an elective splenectomy for hereditary spherocytosis. The surgeon uses a midline incision and divides the short gastric vessels to mobilise the spleen.Which ligament is typically divided during an open splenectomy to rotate and deliver the spleen medially?
questions.solution:
Open Splenectomy

  • Incision: Midline or transverse left subcostal incision.
  • Steps: The spleen is mobilised by dividing the gastrosplenic and lienorenal ligaments, and the splenic vessels are ligated at the pancreas' superior border.
  • Technique: The spleen is carefully rotated and delivered medially into the laparotomy wound.
  • Complications: Splenic bed hematoma, pancreatic injury, and accessory splenic tissue must be considered.

Explanation:

Option A) Incorrect. The gastrosplenic ligament contains short gastric vessels and is divided early during the procedure.

Option B) Incorrect. The hepatoduodenal ligament contains the portal triad and is not involved in splenectomy.

Option C) Incorrect. The phrenicocolic ligament provides support to the spleen but is not divided to mobilise the spleen.

Option D) Correct. The lienorenal ligament is divided during an open splenectomy to mobilise and deliver the spleen medially.

Key Points:

The lienorenal ligament is divided to mobilise the spleen.

questions.text: A 25-year-old male of Mediterranean descent presents with fatigue, pallor, and episodes of dark urine following a recent respiratory infection. He has a history of similar episodes that resolved spontaneously. His lab investigations show anaemia, elevated reticulocyte count, and increased bilirubin. A peripheral blood smear reveals the presence of Heinz bodies. Which of the following statements is true regarding the management of this patient's condition?
questions.solution:
Hemolytic Anaemia Due to Enzyme Deficiency (PKD and G6PD)

G6PD Deficiency:

  • X-linked recessive disorder; common in African, Mediterranean, and Middle Eastern populations.
  • Results in RBC susceptibility to oxidative stress due to lack of NADPH production in the pentose phosphate pathway.
  • Common triggers: infections, fava beans, medications (e.g., sulfa drugs, antimalarials).
  • Management: Primarily avoidance of triggers; splenectomy is rarely indicated.
  • Heinz Bodies: Oxidised haemoglobin precipitates in RBCs, seen on peripheral smear.

Pyruvate Kinase Deficiency (PKD)

  • Autosomal recessive disorder caused by a mutation in the PKLR gene, leading to reduced ATP production in RBCs.
  • Causes chronic hemolysis and may lead to splenectomy if hemolysis is severe.
  • Treatment includes transfusions in severe cases and splenectomy to reduce hemolysis.

Option A) Incorrect. Splenectomy is not the definitive treatment for G6PD deficiency; it is rarely indicated for this condition. However, it may be considered in severe cases of pyruvate kinase deficiency (PKD).

Option B) Correct. G6PD deficiency is managed primarily through the avoidance of oxidative stress triggers, such as infections, fava beans, and certain medications (e.g., sulfa drugs and antimalarials). Patients must be educated about the factors that precipitate hemolysis.

Option C) Incorrect. This patient most likely has G6PD deficiency, based on the episodic nature of the symptoms, the Mediterranean background, and the presence of Heinz bodies, which are more characteristic of G6PD deficiency.

Option D) Incorrect. Transfusion therapy is not routinely required for G6PD deficiency, as most cases are mild and self-limiting. It may only be necessary in cases of severe hemolysis.

Key Points:

G6PD Deficiency: Primarily managed by avoiding triggers; splenectomy is rarely indicated.Pyruvate Kinase Deficiency (PKD): More chronic, splenectomy can be considered in severe cases.

questions.text: A 45-year-old male patient presents with persistent left upper quadrant discomfort 2 years after undergoing splenectomy due to trauma. Imaging reveals multiple small masses scattered throughout the abdominal cavity, which are confirmed to be ectopic splenic tissue. Which of the following statements is correct?
questions.solution:
Splenosis and Accessory Spleens

Splenosis:

  • Autotransplantation of splenic tissue following splenectomy or traumatic injury.
  • Pathophysiology: During trauma or surgery, splenic fragments implant in the abdominal cavity or even thorax, leading to the formation of functioning splenic nodules.
  • Function: These ectopic spleens retain some immunologic function, potentially reducing the risk of post-splenectomy infections.
  • Diagnosis: Usually incidental findings on imaging (CT or MRI) during follow-up after splenectomy. Scintigraphy using heat-damaged red blood cells is diagnostic.

Accessory Spleens (Splenunculi):

  • Congenital small nodules of splenic tissue.
  • Location: Most commonly found near the splenic hilum, gastrosplenic ligament, or tail of the pancreas.
  • Importance in Surgery: Must be searched for during splenectomy to avoid persistence of splenic function, especially in cases of hematologic disorders like idiopathic thrombocytopenic purpura (ITP).

Explanation of Options:

Option A) Incorrect. Splenosis is not congenital. It refers to the autotransplantation of splenic tissue following trauma or surgery.

Option B) Incorrect. Accessory spleens are typically congenital and are located near the tail of the pancreas, gastrosplenic ligament, or splenocolic ligament. They are not multiple and do not function independently from the primary spleen.

Option C) Correct. Splenosis is the process where splenic tissue is scattered throughout the abdominal cavity after trauma or splenic surgery, often reimplanting and functioning as ectopic splenic tissue.

Option D) Incorrect. Splenic tissue in splenosis can contribute to hematologic function, which is important in preventing overwhelming post-splenectomy infection (OPSI).

Key Points:

  • Splenosis: Autotransplantation of splenic tissue after trauma or surgery.
  • Accessory Spleens: Congenital and often located near the pancreas or gastrosplenic ligament.

questions.text: A 35-year-old male is scheduled for an elective splenectomy due to hereditary spherocytosis. He is referred to you for vaccination recommendations preoperatively. What is the most appropriate vaccination strategy to be followed before splenectomy?
questions.solution:
Vaccination in Splenectomy

  • Preoperative Vaccination: Pneumococcal, Meningococcal, and H. influenzae type B vaccines are recommended at least 2 weeks before elective splenectomy.
  • Postoperative Vaccination: If vaccines are not administered preoperatively, they should be given as soon as possible postoperatively, though antibody levels may be lower.
  • Annual Vaccination: Influenza vaccination should be given annually to reduce the risk of secondary bacterial infections.

Explanation:

Option A) Incorrect. PPSV23 should be administered after PCV13, not before, and only after at least 8 weeks.

Option B) Correct. The recommended vaccination schedule for asplenic patients includes PCV13 followed by PPSV23 at least 8 weeks later.

Option C) Incorrect. Asplenic patients require more vaccinations beyond just influenza and meningococcal, including pneumococcal and Haemophilus vaccines.

Option D) Incorrect. Vaccinations should ideally be given 10-12 weeks before elective splenectomy or at least 14 days before surgery.

Key Points:

Preoperative immunization for pneumococcus, meningococcus, and H. influenzae is critical in patients undergoing splenectomy.
